greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A read by antidiagonals: the columns are given by A(n,1)=1, A(n,2)=n+1, A(n,3) = n^2+2n+3, A(n,4) = n^3+3*n^2+6*n+4, A(n,5) = n^4+4*n^3+10*n^2+12*n+7, ..., whose coefficients are given by A104509 (see also A118981).
comment: As pointed out by _Peter Munn_, A117938 gives the same triangle, except that it has an additional diagonal at the right. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Aug 13 2019
example: The first nine rows of A are
maple: for i from 1 to M do A[i,1]:=1; od:
S := series((1 + x^2)/(1-x-x^2 + x*y), x, 120): # this is g.f. for A104509
for n from 1 to M do
f := k-> add( R3[i]*k^(n-i+1), i=1..nops(R3) ): # this is the formula for the (n+1)-st column
for i from 1 to M do A[i,n+1]:=s1[i]; od:
for i from 1 to M do lprint([seq(A[i,j],j=1..M)]); od:
xref: Cf. A104509, A117938, A118980, A118981, A099425 (top row), A006497 (essentially the 2nd row), A014448 (essentially the 3rd row), A087130 (essentially the 4th row).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Aug 12 2019, based on _R. J. Mathar_'s 2011 analysis of A118980.
